source_citation: Mitchell JM et al. MDMA-assisted therapy for severe PTSD. Nat Med. 2021;27(6):1025-1033. doi:10.1038/s41591-021-01336-3
notes: MAPS Phase 3 RCT. Primary endpoint Week 18 CAPS-5. MDMA arm vs. placebo. Response defined as ≥12pt reduction + no longer meeting PTSD criteria; Remission defined as CAPS-5 <33.

source_citation: Mitchell JM et al. MDMA-assisted therapy for moderate to severe PTSD. Nat Med. 2023;29(10):2473-2480. doi:10.1038/s41591-023-02496-6
notes: MAPS Phase 3 replication RCT. MDMA arm vs. placebo. Confirmed MAPP1 results. Remission defined as CAPS-5 ≤11.

source_citation: Goodwin GM et al. Single-dose psilocybin for a treatment-resistant episode of major depression. N Engl J Med. 2022;387(18):1637-1648. doi:10.1056/NEJMoa2206443
notes: Phase 2b dose-finding RCT (1mg vs. 10mg vs. 25mg). 25mg arm shown. Response=≥50% MADRS reduction. Remission=MADRS≤10. Primary endpoint Week 3.

cohort_name: Johns Hopkins Psilocybin MDD (Davis et al. 2021)
source_citation: Davis AK et al. Effects of psilocybin-assisted therapy on major depressive disorder. JAMA Psychiatry. 2021;78(5):481-489. doi:10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2020.3285
notes: Open-label RCT with waitlist control. Two psilocybin sessions (20mg/70kg + 30mg/70kg). GRID-HAMD-17 primary outcome. All sessions monitored.

cohort_name: Imperial College London TRD Psilocybin (Carhart-Harris et al. 2021)
source_citation: Carhart-Harris R et al. Trial of psilocybin versus escitalopram for depression. N Engl J Med. 2021;384(15):1402-1411. doi:10.1056/NEJMoa2032994
notes: Head-to-head RCT psilocybin (n=30) vs. escitalopram (n=29). QIDS-SR-16 primary. Response=≥50% reduction. Remission=score≤5. Escitalopram arm response rate shown for comparison (28%).

cohort_name: Bogenschutz et al. AUD Psilocybin Phase 2 (2022)
source_citation: Bogenschutz MP et al. Percentage of heavy drinking days following psilocybin-assisted psychotherapy. JAMA Psychiatry. 2022;79(10):953-962. doi:10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2022.2096
notes: Phase 2 RCT psilocybin vs. diphenhydramine (active placebo). Primary outcome: % heavy drinking days. 32-week follow-up. AUDIT-C used at baseline and follow-up.

source_citation: Szigeti B et al. Self-blinding citizen science to explore psychedelic microdosing. Elife. / Haijen ECHM et al. Frontiers in Psychiatry. 2023. doi:10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1211862
notes: Largest real-world longitudinal naturalistic psilocybin study. Participants self-administered in non-clinical settings. Also tracked GAD-7, well-being, burnout. >90% positive experience rating.

source_citation: Betzler F et al. Psilocybin-Assisted Therapy for Depressive Disorders: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Metapsy Living Database (depression-psiloctr). doi:10.17605/OSF.IO/58W23
data_freely_usable: Living meta-analysis (Metapsy/Sypres Collaboration). Pooled effect size across all published psilocybin-depression RCTs. n varies by analysis. Hedges g=-0.91 vs. control conditions.

cohort_name: Murrough et al. Ketamine vs. Midazolam MDD (2013)
source_citation: Murrough JW et al. Antidepressant efficacy of ketamine in treatment-resistant major depression. Am J Psychiatry. 2013;170(10):1134-1142. doi:10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.13030392
notes: RCT ketamine (0.5mg/kg IV) vs. midazolam (active control). Primary endpoint 24h post-infusion. Response=≥50% MADRS reduction. Single infusion. TRD population.

cohort_name: Feder et al. Ketamine PTSD RCT (2014)
source_citation: Feder A et al. Efficacy of intravenous ketamine for treatment of chronic posttraumatic stress disorder. JAMA Psychiatry. 2014;71(6):681-688. doi:10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2014.62
notes: Crossover RCT ketamine vs. midazolam. Primary endpoint 24h post-infusion (CAPS total). First RCT of ketamine for PTSD. Substantial symptom reduction with single infusion.
